title: Woman boards Delta flight with no ticket and no ID and refuses to get off the plane for 45 minutes
text:
Authorities in Florida were forced to remove an apparent stowaway from a Delta flight in Orlando after the woman boarded a plane without showing a ticket or I.D. and refused to give up her seat when the assigned passenger showed up.

The passenger, who asked not to be named, said that the unidentified woman protested and threatened her when asked to give her seat, 15A, to its rightful purchaser on flight 1516.

The plane was set to leave Orlando International Airport on its way to Atlanta on Saturday before the commotion caused a major delay.

It took roughly 45 minutes to get the woman to exit the aircraft, authorities said.

An alleged Delta stowaway declined to give up her seat when its assigned passenger arrived on flight 1516 on Saturday

The plane was set to leave Orlando International Airport (pictured) on its way to Atlanta on Saturday before the commotion caused a major delay.

Cell phone audio recordings of the incident show the woman telling the flight's personnel that she had thrown away her boarding pass before getting on the plane

'I also had a boarding pass for that seat, and she said very bluntly, "I'm not moving,"' the seat 15A's assigned passenger told WFTV.

A flight attendant came over and asked the defiant woman to move as well before realizing the accused stowaway wasn't listed on the flight's manifest.

Cell phone audio recordings of the incident show the woman telling the flight's personnel that she had thrown away her boarding pass before getting on the plane.

When asked for identification, the woman showed the flight crew a photo of herself on her phone.

Cell phone video footage shows the commotion as people board flight 1516 in Orlando International Airport on Friday

It's unclear how the alleged stowaway got through Orlando International Airport security onto the flight. Delta Airlines, local and federal authorities are investigating the incident

'Well, I'm showing you a picture ID,' the woman told the flight attendant.

'Ma'am, that's not a government-issued ID. That's a photo,' the stewardess replied.

'Well, this is just as good,' the troublesome passenger rebutted.

'No, ma'am, it's not just as good,' the flight attendant fired back.

Some time later the plane's pilot called Orlando Police.

'They eventually told her, "You're breaking federal law,"' the passenger told WFTV.

Delta Airlines, the Transportation Security Administration and the FBI have also been notified and announced they are investigating the Saturday incident.

The airline issued a statement apologizing for the incident Saturday evening.

'How she got in that airport and how she got on that airplane is extremely concerning,' the anonymous passenger said.
description: The alleged Delta stowaway declined to give up her seat when its assigned passenger arrived on flight 1516 in Orlando on Saturday. The commotion caused a 45 minute flight delay.
